title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #95: Sum of Squared Distance Multiplicities**

For n points in R² with distance multiplicities f(uᵢ), prove ∑f(uᵢ)² ≪ n^{3+ε}.

**Answer: YES** (Guth-Katz 2015)

They proved the stronger bound ∑f(uᵢ)² ≪ n³ log n. Prize: $500.

title: Point
content:
**Point in R²:** A point in 2D Euclidean space.

Defined as EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2), the standard 2D plane.

title: PointConfig
content:
**Point Configuration:** A finite set of points in R².

The input to our problem: n points x₁,...,xₙ. We require at least one point.

title: distanceSet
content:
**Distance Set:** All pairwise distances in a configuration.

If the configuration has t distinct distances, this set has size t.

title: multiplicity
content:
**Distance Multiplicity f(d):** How many pairs of points are exactly distance d apart.

A distance with high multiplicity appears many times among point pairs.

title: sum_multiplicities
content:
**Trivial Sum:** ∑f(uᵢ) = C(n,2) = n(n-1)/2.

Every pair contributes to exactly one distance, so the sum of multiplicities equals the number of pairs.

title: sumSquaredMultiplicities
content:
**Sum of Squared Multiplicities:** ∑f(uᵢ)².

This measures concentration: if all distances are distinct, sum ≈ n²; if one distance dominates, sum can be n⁴.

title: ErdosConjecture
content:
**Erdős's Conjecture:** For all ε > 0, ∑f(uᵢ)² ≪_ε n^{3+ε}.

This bounds how concentrated distances can be. The exponent 3+ε is nearly tight.

title: guth_katz_theorem
content:
**Guth-Katz Theorem (2015):** ∑f(uᵢ)² ≪ n³ log n.

Stronger than Erdős asked:
- No ε in the exponent
- Replace n^ε with log n

Part of their landmark paper on distinct distances.

title: erdos_conjecture_proved
content:
**Erdős's Conjecture is Proved:** Guth-Katz implies the conjecture.

Since log n = o(n^ε) for any ε > 0, the n³ log n bound implies n^{3+ε}.

title: Polynomial Method
content:
**The Guth-Katz Approach:**

1. **Point-Line Duality:** Distances ↔ incidences in 3D
2. **Polynomial Partitioning:** Divide space using algebraic surfaces
3. **Ruled Surfaces:** Lines at same distance form quadric surfaces
4. **Incidence Bounds:** Control point-line incidences

This technique revolutionized combinatorial geometry.

title: convex_polygon_case
content:
**Convex Polygon Case (Fishburn/Altman 1963):** For points in convex position, ∑f(uᵢ)² = O(n³).

The convex case was solved decades before the general case.

title: erdos_95
content:
**Erdős Problem #95: SOLVED**

Main theorem combining:
1. Erdős's conjecture holds
2. With the stronger Guth-Katz bound n³ log n

Prize: $500 (collected by Guth and Katz)
